author: dcspark
title: Self-hosted pricefeed for wallets
description: Currently wallets in Cardano cannot easily display prices of native tokens on Cardano through self-hosted solutions

f6_assessments.q0:
The problem statement raises the issue that currently, wallets on Cardano cannot display the prices of native tokens without relying on a DEX (which is a dependency that should not exist, given principles of decentralization). The proposed solution is an open source tool that provides price information on-chain and that can integrate with wallets. 
The proposal argues that this solution will boost decentralization, solve the problem of relying on the price from a single DEX instead of another by aggregating prices from multiple DEX’s and it would also feed this information to oracles, enabling it to be used by sidechains or layer 2 protocols, like Milkomeda. Furthermore, it would enable new kinds of dApps to be built (it would have been interesting to find out particular examples here).
The proposers have also thought about two risks, namely that the DEX's their Oura tool integrates with could fail, being still relatively new, or they could change how they work, requiring them to update their tool as well. The approach to mitigating these risks relies on the tool’s success: since it will be open source, it will be in the interest of the community to maintain and update it, as long as it’s useful. The proposers also intend on developing it further after they finish what they set out to do in this proposal.
All in all, I think this proposal definitely addresses the Dapps and Integrations challenge effectively, as it would help boost Cardano’s ecosystem further with new tech (score: 5).
f6_assessments.q1:
The roadmap provided by the proposal is a bit simple and only stretches into Q3 of 2022, but it gives a decent image of what the proposal aims to accomplish (integration with 2, maybe 3 DEX’s). I think it would also have been useful here to provide details on how Q4 would look like (a retrospective and analysis of how the tool is used, for example, what quick improvements can be made to it etc).
The budget is broken down into development costs and infrastructure costs and is very reasonable for this proposal in my opinion, at only 45000 USD. Blockchain developers are very expensive and if the team here were inexperienced, I would say it might even be low, but the proposers of this project are dcSpark, a well known and respected company in the blockchain space. I expect they are good at estimating their costs and possibly also have other sources of funding as well (if this is the case, it’s always good to mention in the proposal, as it raises voters’ trust that one way or another, this proposal will be done).
My only observation here is that the proposers should have provided a link to their site, a very short list of the projects they’ve successfully delivered / tools they’ve built (again with references), etc. It’s very useful for voters to have the relevant links inside the proposal, instead of having to google information about the team themselves (it’s highly unlikely the majority of voters takes the time to do that).
That being said, I think it is highly likely for this proposal to be implemented, as dcSpark has a lot of experience with Cardano dApps and the tool they propose to build here seems to be fairly simple (score: 5).
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal is a bit lacking in the Auditability section. It mentions that progress will be measured by the team’s ability to integrate DEX’s into this price feed system, which is of course an important metric, but it does not present key progress indicators that can be tracked until the end goal is reached.
For example, the team could approximate a number of commits per week / month in the project’s github, which can serve as clear evidence that progress is being made.
Also, the proposers mentioned that success would look like many projects using their solution, but this is a vague target.
What voters want to see in the Auditability section is clear numbers that can be publicly tracked and which unequivocally show that a goal has been met. For example: within the first month of the solution being complete, have 1 project using this tool; 3 after 2 months etc.
Again, however, the tool dcSpark proposes to build seems straightforward and due to their reputation, I am quite confident that it will be easy to collaborate with them and obtain the information needed to audit the progress of this proposal. I am giving a score of 4 here, since we rely more on the company’s reputation than the information provided in the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal very successfully makes the case of why the entire ecosystem would benefit from having self-hosted token price feeds for Cardano wallets. The resulting improvements to decentralization and providing reliable information to end-users will undoubtedly have a very positive impact. 

If the project described in this proposal is implemented, it will definitely make DEXs and DeFi in general, more accessible and more credible to many.

I see this proposal as perfectly integrating with the goals of the DApps and Integrations challenge and the overarching goals of Catalyst Fund 8.

The risks and challenges that may arise during the development of this project are also very well described and addressed by the team proving a very thorough understanding of the project they are proposing.
f6_assessments.q1:
The implementation plan is solid and it suggests that the first deliverables of the project should be ready by Q3 2022.

Because the dcSpark team has already developed a wallet in addition to multiple other technical products for the Cardano blockchain I view the implementation of this proposal as very feasible.

The budget breakdown contains only two lines but given the scope of the project that should be sufficient for now as they describe personnel and infrastructure costs. I would have liked to see an hourly rate attached to the development costs but under the circumstances, I view that as a minor omission, and I won't be deducting from my feasibility score for that.

dcSpark, the submitters of this proposal, has a great reputation in the Cardano community as a team that works tirelessly to improve and make contributions to many aspects of the technical side of the ecosystem. I am pretty confident that if the voters choose to fund this proposal the deliverables of this project will get done.

I know that the company has grown in size recently and as such completing the work that is within the scope of this proposal is very feasible.
f6_assessments.q2:
I have only awarded a score of 4 to this section because of the lack of emphasis on providing a clear set of trackable metrics. This would have been necessary especially since funding from the Treasury is released by Project Catalyst on the basis of verifiable reports.

The description of what success looks like is very on point and clearly describes a situation from which the entire Cardano ecosystem will benefit.

Suggestions of things to include in case the proposal is not funded in this round and needs to be submitted in a future one:
	•	A more exact list of KPIs and quantifiable metrics that will enable the progress on this project to be easily verified and tracked by the Catalyst and Cardano community.
	•	Include tangible milestones and goalposts to describe and measure the success of the project, preferably by set timeframes such as 3,6, and 12 months.

f6_assessments.q0: We have seen this similar feature in MuesliSwap and I believe it is highly beneficial to users. I agree with proposed idea that this will support further decentralization, not only in terms of reducing or even eliminating the reliance on centralized APIs provided by DEXs (as mentioned in proposal) but also this feature will help users to migrate from custodial wallet in CEXs to self-custodial wallet connected to DEXs later when a good number of Cardano native assets/token starts to trade in bigger global CEXs. Most people tend to check or track the value of their assets quite frequently, this feature will give more motivation to adopt blockchain native dApps, which in line to the objective of this and add promote adoption as bonus. I am sure everyone in community would love to see this same feature to our AMM DEXs such as SundaeSwap and MinSwap. I also agree that the implementation of this proposal will be a trailblazer to more advancement of dApps in Caradano through more developed oracles for price feed.
f6_assessments.q1: As like what we have seen in MuesliSwap, I think it is very attainable to see the same in our AMM DEXs. Teams at dcSpark have also been in Cardano for a long time and proven themselves through Milkomeda, Flint, Fracada, etc as mentioned in the proposal. Sebastian himself is one of the people in our community who actually and highly understands Ouroboros whitepaper well, as testified by Charles in one of his Twitter Spaces. However, I hope dcSpark could give more details in the team breakdown (maybe by introducing which engineer will oversee the development of this proposal) or just simply introduce themselves more through their website or GitHub so CAs or voters new to Cardano can discover and understand their record of accomplishment better. In terms of expertise and technical capability, I trust dcSpark can deliver this to our community though I hope they can be more resource-efficient in terms of time and fund since dcSpark is a quite frequent and prolific proposer in Project Catalyst.
f6_assessments.q2: Although we can easily know if this proposal delivered and worth the fund invested by looking and interacting with the implemented DEXs later this year, I expect that proposer could elaborate a bit more the content of the proposal along with more quantitative metrics. For example, maybe they can advise the number of new Cardano native oracles that will utilize the product of this proposal. Though in essence people with enough understanding might be able to visualize the whole process and outcome, general audience will need to see and read more to dive deeper into the quality of this proposal. Therefore, I would love to rate this proposal higher in this particular aspect but the lack of details and elaboration prevented me from doing so.

solution: We will deploy an Oura source+sink that parses on-chain dApp data to provide an open-source self-hosted price feed that wallets can use
experience: dcSpark has experience writing wallet software (such as Flint Wallet which uses a custom backend we wrote), we have experience with Oura (we've been rewriting cardano-db-sync in Oura) and we have experience with Cardano dApps (we've written open source dApps such as Fracada)
